info.game_comments:
2001 Holiday Kids Week game 5.

(Cheryl: Hi, I'm Cheryl of the Clue Crew.  You must at least be this tall to play on Jeopardy! today.  Stay tuned.)

jeopardy_round: I'M TALL ENOUGH TO RIDE THAT!

(1, 1).clue: This nickname of a Native American woman, Chief Powhatan's daughter, means "playful one"

(2, 1).clue: Put this legume spread on your tongue; either smooth or chunky is okay

(3, 1).clue: You'll find the world's most famous pyramids in this northern African country

(4, 1).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew outside on a toy.)  I'm hoping to break Gary Stewart's record of 177,737 jumps on one of these

(5, 1).clue: The glazing or frosting on a birthday cake

(6, 1).clue: 36" tall? You're big enough for Racing Rapids at Kennywood, near Pittsburgh in this state

(1, 2).clue: Born in Weymouth, Massachusetts in 1744, she was wife of one President & the mother of another

(2, 2).clue: Drink a glass of water while you squeeze this body part that contains a septum

(3, 2).clue: Like mausoleums, the ancient pyramids were originally built to be used as these

(4, 2).clue: A special edition of Trivial Pursuit focuses on this movie series, with categories about characters, weapons & droids

(5, 2).clue: Two-word namefor the popular methodof cold-weather transportseen here

(6, 2).clue: Seen here is the Big Shot, which you have to be 4 feet tall to ride on the Stratosphere Tower in this Nevada city

(1, 3).clue: The money this "Little Women" author received for her fiction made her the main breadwinner for her family

(2, 3).clue: Try chewing this confection usually made of chicle (but make sure you've got enough for the entire class)

(3, 3).clue: It's the name for the typeof preserved human seen here

(4, 3).clue: You can launch your medical career with this classic game of skill that features "Cavity Sam"

(5, 3).clue: Use your noodle.It's the country seen here

(6, 3).clue: Make sure you're at least 42" tall if you want to ride Grizzly River Run at this new theme park next to Disneyland

(1, 4).clue: The 300 slaves she escorted to freedom on the underground railroad included her brother, sister & parents

(2, 4).clue: Breathe into a bag for a minute; this gas, CO2, can disrupt the nerve impulses which cause hiccups

(3, 4).clue: Little is known of the builders of the pyramids of the sun & moon at Teutihuacan in this country

(4, 4).clue: Gingerbread men make their way through Peppermint Stick Forest in this board game

(5, 4).clue: When describing rocks it means "formerly molten"

(6, 4).clue: When you hit 54", get on the Mantis, a stand-up scream machine at Cedar Point in this "Buckeye State"

(1, 5).clue: Famous student seen here on a stamp with her teacher,Anne Sullivan

(3, 5).clue: It's the large mythological creature that "guards" the pyramids

(4, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew outside with a toy.) Leash laws don't apply to this yo-yo trick

(5, 5).clue: Homer's other epic Greek poem besides "The Odyssey"

(6, 5).clue: You must be 48" tall to ride the Busch Gardens roller coaster named for this Scottish "Monster"

(1, 1).clue: Almost every spring kids come to the White House to roll & hunt these

(2, 1).clue: Types of this animal include appaloosas, palominos & pintos

(3, 1).clue: March 28, 2001: Hmm..."Hip Hoppin; Howdy Diddy"...That's not right..."P. Diddy"!  That's the name I'll call myself!

(4, 1).clue: Footwear from this company includes the Air Edge Max V & the Air Jordan XVI

(5, 1).clue: You can breathe easier knowing that these paired organs are central to the respiratory system

(1, 2).clue: 140 people can sit down to supper in the room seen here, known as the State this

(2, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew at the Parrot Jungle in Miami.) Of fruit, leaves, or insects, it's the one that makes up most of an orangutan's diet

(3, 2).clue: June 25, 1876: Leading the men to Little Bighorn to capture an Indian village; how hard could that be?

(5, 2).clue: If someone says, "Your epidermis is showing", he's referring to the outermost layer of this

(6, 2).clue: An abbreviation for a compass direction

(1, 3).clue: This first President named Roosevelt made the name "White House" official, putting it on his stationery

(2, 3).clue: Histah was Tarzan's word for this kind of reptile, though hisstah would be more appropriate

(3, 3).clue: 1975: One day I'll be so rich I could buy my own island, maybe Australia. Starting Microsoft with my pal Paul is a good start

(4, 3).clue: The name of this company that makes classic weatherproof boots means "a forested area"

(5, 3).clue: The middle part of this organ contains 3 tiny bones called the hammer, anvil & stirrup

(6, 3).clue: A USDA top grade of poultry

(1, 4).clue: It was built in 1902, expanded in size in 1909 & 1934 & is now the the title of a popular TV show

(2, 4).clue: Peppy, this type of bird, was created as the symbol of Wise potato chips

(3, 4).clue: Sept. 14, 1812: Feelin' good; occupied Moscow today. Josephine would have been impressed

(4, 4).clue: This brand's Kobe comes in kids' sizes, too

(5, 4).clue: The 3 main types of blood vessels are capillaries, veins & these, which carry blood from the heart

(6, 4).clue: The 21st letter of the English alphabet

(1, 5).clue: This glamorous First Lady redecorated the White House when she lived there, 1961-1963

(2, 5).clue: (Sofia & Sarah of the Clue Crew holding a creature.) This six-letter word for this rare alligator comes from the Latin for "white"

(3, 5).clue: 1876: Finished writing "Tom Sawyer" but folks'll have to wait 8 years for a sequel

(4, 5).clue: This shoe style was named for a girl in a comic strip

(5, 5).clue: In an emergency this hormone prepares you for "fight or flight"

(6, 5).clue: At the beginning of some last names it's used to indicate "grandson of"

(0, 0).clue: NORAD's annual tracking of his flight progress goes back to 1955 & now has a website
